conclusion: The capacitor plates are connected to a power supply providing a constant voltage V. The distance between the capacitor plates is d. The thickness of the metal plate is l and it is placed on the lower plate.
When the metal plate is present, it effectively reduces the electric field between the capacitor plates.
The capacitance of the parallel-plate capacitor without the metal plate is given by C = ε₀A/d where ε₀ is the permittivity of free space and A is the area of the plates.
With the metal plate, which is a conductor, the electric field within it is zero, and the field between the plates is effectively reduced. The effective distance becomes d - l.
When the metal plate is removed, the electric field E between the plates becomes E = V/d.
The particle P is initially stationary, which means the net force acting on it is zero.
The forces acting on the particle are the electric force Fe due to the electric field and the gravitational force Fg.
The electric force on the particle is Fe = qE = q(V/d) where q is the charge of the particle.
The gravitational force on the particle is Fg = mg where m is the mass of the particle and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
Initially, the net force is zero: qE = mg thus q(V/d) = mg.
When the metal plate is removed, the net force on the particle is F_net = ma = Fe - Fg.
Substituting Fe and Fg: ma = q(V/d) - mg.
From the initial condition q(V/d) = mg, it follows that F_net = mg - mg = 0.
The acceleration a of the particle is a = g.
